title: Sources
text:
Dataset: Life Expectany Analysis 

Author: Naila Srivastava

Publisher: Kaggle

URL: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/nailasrivastava/life-expectancy-analysis

Accessed: August 6, 2025


This dataset provides health and economic indicators for over 190 countries from 2000 to 2015. It is used in this project to analyze factors affecting life expectancy.

title: Predicting Life Expectancy
text:
Summary
How do health and socioeconomic factors influence life expectancy globally?
I used data compiled by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Development Programme, covering health and socioeconomic indicators for over 190 countries from 2000 to 2015. After cleaning and standardizing the data, I focused on comparing the effect of economic resources, education levels, and disease prevalence on national life expectancy.
I built a multiple linear regression model to predict life expectancy (measured in years), using factors such as adult mortality, HIV/AIDS prevalence, years of schooling, and national income levels. The model showed that higher income composition increased life expectancy by +10.8 years, while HIV/AIDS prevalence and adult mortality had negative effects of −0.44 and −0.02 years, respectively.
Income inequality and health interventions can shift life expectancy by more than a decade — and that gap may grow without investment in education and disease prevention.

title: About this site
text:
My name is Inam Ullah Khan, a master’s student in Data Science at Al-Farabi Kazakh National University. You can find my work on GitHub, and reach me at Gmail.
This website summarizes my project on predicting life expectancy using global health and socio-economic data. You can explore the full project and code on this GitHub repository.
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Model
text:
We fit a multiple linear regression model to predict life expectancy based on several key health and socioeconomic indicators.
The model is defined as:
\[
\text{Life Expectancy} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Adult Mortality} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{Income Composition of Resources} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{HIV/AIDS} + \beta_4 \cdot \text{Schooling} + \beta_5 \cdot \log(\text{GDP} + 1) + \epsilon
\]
Where:

\(\beta_0\) is the intercept
\(\epsilon\) is the error term

title: Model
text:
We fit a multiple linear regression model to predict life expectancy based on several key health and socioeconomic indicators.
The model is defined as:
\[
\text{Life Expectancy} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Adult Mortality} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{Income Composition of Resources} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{HIV/AIDS} + \beta_4 \cdot \text{Schooling} + \beta_5 \cdot \log(\text{GDP} + 1) + \epsilon
\]
Where:

\(\beta_0\) is the intercept
\(\epsilon\) is the error term

title: Model
text:
Data Generating Mechanism (DGM)
The estimated equation from the model is:
\[
\text{Life Expectancy} = 51.16 - 0.02 \cdot \text{Adult Mortality} + 10.80 \cdot \text{Income/Resources} - 0.44 \cdot \text{HIV/AIDS} + 0.99 \cdot \text{Schooling} + 0.48 \cdot \log(\text{GDP} + 1) + \epsilon
\]

Adult Mortality is measured per 1,000 people.
Income Composition of Resources is on a 0–1 scale.
HIV/AIDS prevalence is a percentage.
Schooling is in years of education.
GDP is transformed using log(GDP + 1) to reduce skewness.

Interpretation

Adult Mortality and HIV/AIDS are strongly associated with lower life expectancy.
Schooling, Income Composition, and GDP are positively associated with higher life expectancy.
All predictors are statistically significant at p < 0.001.

text:
Predictor Relationships
